Abstract
text: This paper presents in implemented theory for quantifying noun phrases in clauses containing copular verbs (e.g.. 'be' and 'become.).
Proceeding from recent theoretical work by Jackendolf WWI, this computational theory recognizes the dependence ()I' the quantification decision on the definiteness.

Jackendoffs intuition about the quantilicational interdependence of subject and object has been imported from his broader cognitive theory and reformulated within a constraint propagation framework, Extensions reported here include.
the addition of more active determiners.
the expansion of determiner categories, and the treatment or displaced objects.
A further finding is that quantilicational constraints may propagate across some clausal boundaries.

The algorithm is used by the RELATUS Natural Language Understanding System during a phase of analysis that posts constraints to produce a 'constraint tree.' This phase conies after creation of syntactic deep structure and before sentential reference in a semantic-network model.

Incorporation of the quantification algorithm in a larger system that parses sentences and builds semantic models from them makes RELATUS able to acquire taxonotnic and identity information from text.

Recent interest in developing lexicons to support computer understanding of natural language [Walker and Amsler, 19851 suggests the need for effective methods of augmenting our lexicographical knowledge using large corpora and unrestricted text.
Selection restrictions are an important type of information to accumulate because they are needed not only to distinguish different senses of words but also to recognize metaphorical uses.
Since accumulation of selection restrictions requires it, acquisition of taxonomic information is a priority.
The copular interconstraint algorithm introduced in this paper provides a basis fbr acquiring large taxonomies from unrestricted texts.
A lifter can he used to quickly prune all non-copular sentences zis well as difficult copular sentences involving belief, and perhaps, time contexts.
The remaining sentences can be parsed, quantified and represented in a large semantic model.

This research would not only advance our knowledge of natural taxonomies and selection restrictions hut it would also generate empirical data useful Ibr those studying 'default logics and stereotype hierarchies [Minsky, 1975; Keil, 1979; Reiter, 1980; Brachman, 1982; Etherington and Reiter, 19831.

One difficulty with this research program is that an uncertainty principle is at work: The taxonomy used to determine selection restrictions itself depends on recognition of metaphors through selection restrictions.
Success in this lexicographical task will require the careful development of effective research strategies.
